questions.question: How does the arrival rate of customers affect the behavior of an M/G/1/N queueing system?

answers.a: Higher arrival rate leads to shorter waiting times
answers.b: Lower arrival rate reduces system utilization
answers.c: Increased arrival rate may lead to system instability
answers.d: Arrival rate has no impact on system performance

explanations.a: Incorrect. A higher arrival rate often results in longer waiting times as the queue becomes more congested.
explanations.b: Incorrect. A lower arrival rate may reduce congestion but does not necessarily affect overall system utilization.
explanations.c: Correct. An increased arrival rate relative to the service rate can lead to system instability, potentially causing congestion and delays.
explanations.d: Incorrect. The arrival rate directly influences system performance, especially in terms of congestion and waiting times.

questions.question: How does the assumption of general service time distributions (M/G/1/N) differ from assuming exponential service times (M/M/1/N) in a queueing system?

answers.a: M/G/1/N model allows for more flexible analysis of non-exponential service times
answers.b: M/M/1/N model guarantees shorter waiting times
answers.c: M/G/1/N model always results in higher system utilization
answers.d: M/M/1/N model is more suitable for high arrival rate scenarios

explanations.a: Correct. The M/G/1/N model allows for more flexible analysis by accommodating non-exponential service time distributions, which may better represent real-world scenarios.
explanations.b: Incorrect. The choice between M/G/1/N and M/M/1/N models depends on various factors, and neither model guarantees shorter waiting times inherently.
explanations.c: Incorrect. System utilization depends on various factors beyond the choice of service time distribution model.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Both M/G/1/N and M/M/1/N models can be suitable for different scenarios, and neither is inherently more suitable for high arrival rate scenarios.

questions.question: How does the finite system capacity 'N' affect the trade-off between waiting time and system utilization?

answers.a: Higher 'N' results in shorter waiting times but lower system utilization
answers.b: Lower 'N' leads to higher system stability but longer waiting times
answers.c: Higher 'N' always ensures higher system utilization
answers.d: System utilization remains unaffected by the value of 'N'

explanations.a: Correct. Increasing 'N' allows more customers to wait in the system simultaneously, reducing waiting times but potentially lowering system utilization.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Lowering 'N' may reduce system stability but does not necessarily guarantee longer waiting times.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Higher 'N' can lead to higher system utilization in some scenarios, but it depends on various factors.
explanations.d: Incorrect. The value of 'N' directly affects system utilization, especially to the trade-off with waiting time.

questions.question: How does variability in arrival rates impact the behavior of an M/G/1/N queueing system?

answers.a: Higher variability always leads to longer waiting times
answers.b: Lower variability guarantees higher system stability
answers.c: Variability does not affect system performance
answers.d: Variability may result in unpredictable system behavior

explanations.a: Incorrect. Variability in arrival rates can lead to unpredictable effects on waiting times, not necessarily always longer.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Lower variability may contribute to stability but does not guarantee it, as other factors also influence system stability.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Variability can significantly impact system performance, especially in terms of waiting times and congestion.
explanations.d: Correct. Variability in arrival rates may lead to unpredictable fluctuations in system behavior, affecting waiting times and congestion.
